title: (x) Nike "Witness" ad campaign - Stymie {Michael Albright}
content:
Does anyone know what typeface Nike used for their “Witness” ad campaign?  
 [http://www.hotrodsworld.com/images/nike-witness-poster.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20081120064952/http:/www.hotrodsworld.com/images/nike-witness-poster.jpg)

 [‹ (x) Irish Railway wayfinding signs - Córas Iompair Éireann (CIE) corporate typeface {Conor}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081120064952/http:/www.typophile.com/node/35215 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Looking for alternatives to Aviano ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081120064952/http:/www.typophile.com/node/35470 "Go to next forum topic")
author: davez0r

comments.content: No, not Memphis. W and S don’t match. Stymie is closer but not exactly it. Maybe customized.

Keep an open mind and look at the W and S a little closer. Imagine the addition of a central slab (W & E) and the pulling of a couple of points (S) ?!?

;^)
I have to admit, my mind isn’t all that open today. Memphis Bold at least seems to have the right weight. And I overread the “customised“.

\> I have to admit, my mind isn’t all that open today.

Dont’ worry. Here in the background, black and white, is the Nike Witness. In blue, at 87% opacity, is [Bitstream Stymie Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20081120064952/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/stymie/bold/).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081120064952im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/BitstreamStymie_5117.jpg)

[edit] PS. Comparing a text written white on black to one written black on white is tricky, because of optical illusions.
